loans.name: Lucianitas Santa Lucia Group 2

texts.en:
The town of Santa Lucia is the town where all the members of the group are born. They like their town because it is quiet and safe. There is never any violence or other negative things happening. Even though they know each other well, there is never time to chat to each other. This is because these women are overwhelmed with the household chores such as preparing meals for the entire family, washing clothes, working, etc. For that reason, these women are very happy with the repayment meetings and the informal education training Friendship Bridge offers to all the clients. 

The members of the group work in various businesses such as raising animals, administering a small restaurant, administering a beauty salon, administering a school for hair stylists, and selling fruit at the market of Sololá. Hilaria invited her daughter and niece to the group. These two young and modern women sell jewelry to acquaintances in Sololá. They are able to take care of their expenses while attending school with the revenue from their business. This aspect of their work is very encouraging. This means that, through microfinance, a woman can pay her expenses throughout school without relying on anybody else. 

Faustina, the group leader, tells me she raises small pigs until they are big, and then they are sold to an intermediary who always buys the pigs from her and her sisters, who are members of another trust bank.

Another group member, Aura, who is 8 months pregnant, wants to invest her credit in buying an extra chair for her beauty salon. This way she can teach more people how to cut hair. She tells me with a smile how more young people cut and style their hair than before. In the past, women grew their hair since they were young. Cutting their hair wasn’t the fashion then. Instead, they just trimmed it a couple of inches. 

The women formed the group after they had a visit from one of the loan officers called Catarina. They hope to be able maintain this pleasant path of improving their lives. Because some of them only went to school when they were kids, they would really like to be able to provide their own children a better future through education.

loans.use: Invest in a greater quantity and range of products

loans.name: Nidia Marilu

texts.es:
Nidia is a member of the Rikchary Community Bank. Rikchary means "to wake up" in Quecha.

Nidia is 30 years old and married with 2 children. With her husband, she has two businesses, one is a tavern called "Ucupis," which means "with in" in Quecha. The tavern is open all night until the early morning, because of which she employes people to work in her business. Also, Nidia has a liquor store which is located on the main street. The liquor store is open at night until the early morning as well, depending on the demand for her products. She also sells beer at various events.

Nidia also has a business in which she is the sole owner, a mail-order cosmetic product and clothing business in the city of Lima.

Nidia needs a 2,000 soles loan to purchase children's and women's clothing. Nidia dreams of having her own house, expanding her businesses, and offering the best to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

Nidia es socia del Banco Comunal Rikchary que significa Despierta en quechua.

Nidia es casada, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Nidia junto a su esposo tiene dos negocios que es administrado por ambos, tienen una taberna llamado Ucupis que significa adentro en quechua, la atención es por las noches hasta la madrugada, para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda de personal. Además tienen una licorería que se ubica en una avenida principal, el horario de atención es por las noches hasta la madrugada dependiendo de la demanda de sus productos y también reparte cerveza por mayor a diferentes eventos de acuerdo a los pedidos.

Nidia además tiene un negocio que ella sola administra que es la venta de cosméticos por catálogos y ropa que lo adquiere en la ciudad de Lima.

Nidia necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa de niños y damas. Los sueños de Nidia son tener casa propia, ampliar sus negocios, que sus ventas sigan creciendo y brindarles los mejor a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase children's and women's clothing.

loans.name: Esperanza Yolanda

texts.es:
Esperanza ('hope' in english) is a member of the Rickchary Community Bank. Rickchary means, "to wake up" in Quechua.

Esperanza is 35 years old and married with 4 children. Many years ago Esperanza owned a grocery store which she closed due to credit problems. Since then she has looked for other business opportunities, and as her husband was a topographer, she acquired topography machines which she currently rents out to people and business that need them. Also, Esperanza has a small book store which is growing little by little.

Esperanza needs a 1,600 soles loan to purchase a photocopier.

Esperanza dreams of building a house, growing her business, and sending her children to universities.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

Esperanza es socia del Banco Comunal Rikchary que significa Despierta en quechua.

Esperanza es casada, tiene 35 años y 4 hijos, Esperanza hace muchos años tenia una tienda de abarrotes negocio que cerró debido a que vendió al crédito y no le cancelaron, por lo que Esperanza busco otras oportunidades de negocios y como su esposo era topógrafo, adquirió equipos topográficos que actualmente alquila a instituciones y personas que necesitan de este equipo, además tiene una pequeña tienda de venta de artículos de librería que poco a poco esta surtiendo.

Esperanza necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de una fotocopiadora.

Esperanza sueña con construir su casa, surtir más su negocio y que sus hijos estudien en universidades particulares.

loans.use: Purchase a photocopier

loans.name: Miriam Margot

texts.es:
Miriam is a member of the Rikchary Community Bank. Rickchary means "to wake up" in Quechua.

Miriam is 24 years old, and lives with her partner and two children. She is a traveling sweets saleswoman in the central park of Ayacucho. Miriam usually positions herself in front of the bank, which she relies on to purchase some of her products. She works every day from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. Sometimes Miriam travels to different provinces and villages to sell her sweets when there are festivals.

Miriam needs a loan of 1,000 soles, which she will use to purchase cigarettes, gum, and cookies.

Miriam dreams of studying cosmetology and opening a beauty salon in her neighborhood, selling more products, and her children becoming professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

Miriam es socia del Banco Comunal Rikchary que significa Despierta en quechua.

Miriam es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Miriam vende golosinas de manera ambulatoria en el parque central de la ciudad de Ayacucho, Miriam diariamente se ubica al frente de un Banco para lo cual cuenta una pequeña fuente en la que coloca sus golosinas, actividad que realiza todos los días desde las 5 de la mañana hasta las 11 de la noche. En algunas oportunidades Miriam viaja a las diferentes provincias, pueblos en donde se realizan diferentes fiestas o eventos.

Miriam necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cigarros, chicles, galletas.

Miriam sueña con estudiar cosmetología para implementar un salón de belleza en su barrio, vender otros productos y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase cigarettes, gum and cookies to sell.

loans.name: Paen

texts.en: Mrs. Paen C. is a villager in Sdao Kanlaeng Village in Kandal Province. She is 39 years old and married without any children. She and her husband, Mr. Bo Virak, are fishermen who catch fish, but only small numbers because they do not have enough equipment. Additionally, Mrs. Paen C.'s boat does not have an engine, making it difficult for her to go fishing. In order to catch more fish and make the boat faster, Mrs. Paen C. asks for a loan to buy a boat engine. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a boat engine to gather more fish.

loans.name: Ith

texts.en: Mrs. Ith C. is a 48-year-old widow with a 26-year-old child who helps her in her business activities. Mrs. Ith C. is a scarf middleman in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province. Aside from this business, she is a poultry breeder who raises about 120 chickens. Since Mrs. Ith C.'s family now lives in an old house and in poor conditions, she wants to improve her standard of living.  She asks for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family.

loans.use: To help to build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Im, 28, raises pigs and lives with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Sarn San, is a marble carver. They both live in Roleap Commune, Pursat Province. She purchases piglets to raise to sell three times a year. The piglets just take two to three months to raise.

Because of the increased price of meat, she can generate more profit. She wants to grow her business, and she needs to purchase more piglets to breed. She faces the obstacle of lacking money to use as capital, and now she has decided to request a loan. She will use the loan for her pig-raising business and for her husband to purchase marble for his carving business.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to breed

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en:
Ilhomjon E., a 49-year-old farmer who has been working the land since 2004, is married with three children.  He is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults thanks to his example. During the season, Ilhomjon works in the field from early morning until late at night. 

Now that the business is stable, Ilhomjon believes it will be the main income for his family in the future. He is therefore requesting $600 for the term of six months in order to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. He thanks all who support him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
Zafar F. is a 30-year-old farmer raising three children with his wife.  Deeply spiritual and physically strong, he has five years of farming experience sowing potatoes, cucumbers, carrots, and tomatoes which he then sells at the local market. Each day he works diligently to make sure that he takes good care of his crops; his meticulous practices enable him to support both his family and his parents.

Zafar is now requesting a loan of $450 for a term of nine months in order to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. Zafar thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
Rustam H., 51 and married with three children, has been operating a grocery store for the past eight years. Assisted by his son in the selling of foodstuffs including tea, soft drinks, bread, chocolates and a variety of sweets, he has established a successful business through hard and diligent work. 

Rustam’s main goal is to give his dearest children a good education and make them happy. In order to cover the higher education expenses of his younger son as he prepares to enter the university, Rustam wants to increase his working capital to expand the range of goods that he sells.  Therefore he is requesting a loan of $600 for the term of nine months. He thanks everyone for their support and promises to repay the loan on time. Be an important part of the growth of Rustam’s business. He is counting on your help

loans.use: To increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Amin

texts.en:
Amin Z. is 43 years old and the father of three children.  He and his wife are raising them with love and trying to ensure they have everything that teenagers may need. Working hard to attain a better lifestyle and rise out of poverty, Amin operates a workshop where he repairs electronic equipment such as televisions, tape recorders, and radios. He has been involved in this field for over 13 years and has gained a vast amount of experience. His shop is located near a very busy market, which has allowed him to establish a stable volume of clients. 

Amin is now requesting a loan of $1000 in order to purchase the spare parts necessary for his business. He hopes to thereby increase his income and be able to send his sons to the university. Amin promises to repay the loan within nine months, and your support will really help him. Let us make it possible for this noble father to earn, through his work as a radio technician, enough to provide for the wellbeing of his beloved family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for development of the business.

loans.name: Khosiyat

texts.en:
Khosiyat R., 35 years old and married with three children, has been selling office and school supplies for the past five years. Her husband is currently unemployed, so Khosiyat’s business is the family’s main source of income. Her  trading place is located in the central market, and the majority of her customers are schoolchildren. 

Khosiyat’s goods are currently in great demand as the opening of school approaches, so she would like to take this opportunity to increase the range of goods that she sells. Therefore she is requesting a loan of $600 for a term of 10 months to purchase additional supplies.  Khosiyat is hoping to continue in her entrepreneurial pursuit and achieve stability and success.

loans.use: To purchase addional supplies to sell

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Mr. L. Phorn, 31, is a builder of Khmer-style houses. He is married and has two children. He lives in Kampong Choeung Commune, Kampong Thom Province. He is a skilled builder and earns money from house owners when he completes their houses, and sometimes owners pay half the amount up front. When customer demand increases, sometimes he goes far from home to build houses and has to spend a lot of time traveling.

To reduce the expenses of traveling and make his job easier, he decided to request a loan to purchase a motorcycle to use to travel to his construction jobs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use to travel to his construction jobs

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusuf S., 35, and married with one son, lives in Isfara, Tajikistan. An animated man filled with enthusiasm, Yusuf works hard preparing and selling the national pie called “sambusa” (flour with meat baked in coals according to the old recipes he acquired from his mother) in a small place which he rents. He would like to expand his business and ultimately have his own establishment where he can offer more to his customers; as well, he wishes to buy a refrigerator in order to sell cold drinks. 

Yusuf is requesting a loan of $700 for a 10 month term to purchase the foodstuffs needed to prepare “sambusa” and develop his business, thereby increasing his income. With his efforts, and your important contribution, he can achieve his goals.

loans.use: To purchase the foodstuffs necessary for preparing the national pie “sambusa” and develop his business

loans.name: Mamadjon

texts.en:
Mamadjon R. is 41 years old and the father of two adorable children. His wife is a housekeeper. Mamadjon provides transportation services, a business he has been involved in for 20 years, within the cities of Khujand-Gafurov. With his savings he was able to purchase his own minivan, and the business is stable, providing the main source of income for his family. 

Mamadjon plans to fix his van in order to provide higher quality services in the future, so he is requesting a loan of $400 for a four month term to purchase new tires. This will be Mamadjon’s first loan and he would like to thank all for their support and promises to be prompt in his loan repayment. He is counting on your help.

loans.use: To purchase tires for the minivan

loans.name: Naseem M. Zahid Group

texts.en:
Naseem Baji is the widow of M. Zahid and lives in a small city named Chichawatni, Pakistan. Her husband left her at the time when her daughters were young. Without any support, Naseem Baji worked hard and improved the education of her daughters. All of her daughters completed their education to the 10th standard.

She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She bought wood with her first loan. She cuts the wood into pieces and sells it in the community. She chose this profession because gas is not available in her area and people burn the wood for cooking. Now she is applying for a loan for the same business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sajida Baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for hauling. Shabana Baji wants a loan to buy food (rice and cooking oil) for her food business. Sakina Baji and Hashmat Baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy woods to increase her profit

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is married to N. A. and lives in a small city called Chichawatni, in Pakistan. She is the mother of five sons and two daughters. Her eldest son operates a tractor; the other runs his own food business and a small hotel. Razia is a housewife and prefers to care for the household. She has successfully completed her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. She is now applying for her second loan to purchase more materials such as oil, rice, and lentils to support her son’s food business.

Razia also has additional members in her loan group. They would like to purchase various items, such as wood, fruits, and a sewing machine to power their own businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, and be used to support each respective business. All of the group members support one another- if one of them fails to repay, the others are responsible and will contribute to the group total.

loans.use: To purchase food and cooking materials

loans.name: Rajan's Group

texts.en:
Rajan baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a small city named Chichawatni, Pakistan. She is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.

Rajan baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She invested her share in her husband's business. Her husband made a cycle stand where people come to stand their cycles and he gives a token to them and charges a fee.

Presently her husband is doing nothing; because of some circumstances he failed to continue the business. Now Rajan baji is applying for a loan to start a grocery shop for her husband and to buy groceries she requires a loan.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Razia baji wants a loan to buy food ingredients (cooking oil, rice, wheat) for her food business. Hafizan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Khalida baji and Saima baji each want a loan to buy shoes for their shoe-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is the wife of J. H.. She lives in the small city of Chichawatni, Pakistan. She is the mother of nine children: seven sons and two daughters. Sakina's baji's elder son has a wood business. The next eldest son has a grocery shop. Her younger son is a daily wage laborer. Sakina baji and her daughters prefer to stay at home and do household work. Sakina baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a Pakistan microfinance institute). She invested the loan amount in her son's grocery shop. Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries to diversify her son's grocery shop into a grocery store.

Sakina baji is joined in her loan group by four other members. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy shoes for her shoe selling business. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy leather to resell. Muniran baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran baji is a wife of M. A. and lives in the small city of Chichawatni, Pakistan. She is the mother of three sons. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the last 5 years. Her husband has been selling electrical supplies since last year. Sugran baji is a housewife and prefers to do domestic work and take care of her sons. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a Pakistan microfinance institute). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more electrical goods (switches, tube lights, switch boards) for her husband's shop.

Sugran baji is joined in her loan group by four other members. Anwari baji wants a loan to buy more fruits to resell. Shamshad baji wants a loan to buy food material (cooking oil, rice and wheat) for her food business. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Mukhtaran baji wants a loan to buy shoes for her shoe selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy electrical goods

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 30 years old and married with 2 children, aged 10 and 14. She became a food seller in 2005. Every day she works from 7 AM to 3 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Mwanahawa now hopes for a loan to buy more food items like rice, maize flour, vegetables and bananas to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell.

loans.name: Mosi's Sisi Kwa Sisi Group

texts.en:
Mosi is 30 years old and married with 4 children, aged between 14 and 7. She also takes care of 4 other people between 20 and 60 years old. She has been a perfume seller since 2005. Every day she works from 7 AM to 4 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Mosi now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with food sales, firewood and charcoal sales, and clothes sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Ramla

texts.en:
Ramla is 25 years old and is married. She has been a clothes seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 9:00 A.M. to 5:00 P.M. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Ramla now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Dul

texts.en: Mrs. Dul M. is a villager in Kos Prak Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband are employed at an embassy in Cambodia. Mrs. Dul M. is 21 years old and the mother of two children, age three and one. Mrs. Dul M.'s family now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to fix her house. Therefore, she is requesting a loan for this purpose. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng Y. was born in 1949 and she now lives in Preak Takeo Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Kang Nov, are farmers who cultivate twice a year.  It is now the rainy season and Mrs. Heng Y. needs to cultivate rice.  Since she does not have enough money to plant seedlings, she asks for a loan to buy rice seeds and to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow her field. Mrs. Heng Y. has two children one of whom is employed in a security guard company while the other sells grocery products in Phnom Penh, Cambodian city. Her husband is shown on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and she would use the part of the loan to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow her field.

loans.name: Mgeni's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Mgeni is 33 years old and married with 2 children, aged 6 and 3. She has been a clothes seller since 2003. Every day she works from 8 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Mgeni now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Asha and Jokha.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina is 45 years old. She is divorced with one child who is 30 years old. She has been a bread seller since 2005. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

Zaina now hopes for a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her bread-selling business

loans.name: Mohab Allah

texts.en:
Mohab Allah is 20 years old. He graduated school one year ago, and began work at a retail shop left over from his father. His father had been running the family store for more than ten years, but was unable to continue, and Mohab had to take over.

Mohab, who is a hard worker, is requesting a loan to expand his store. He would like to complete his lease purchase and continue to extend his customer base to support his family. Mohab is very happy to be involved in the loaning process, and was overjoyed when he applied for AFSG. He would like to take the opportunity and thank any lenders who will help him and his family.

loans.use: To complete his lease purchase

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en: Mrs. Phorn S. lives in Roka Village in Kandal Province. She is a 46-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other works as a construction worker. Mrs. Phorn S. is a farmer in the local village. Since her plantation field has infertile soil, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support her field and to buy rice seeds to cultivate.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her field and to buy rice seeds to cultivate.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Mrs. Phon L. is a villager in Roka Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Son Soeun, are farmers who cultivate twice a year. They have three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and one who is a housewife who can make a small salary. Since the two children's work place is far from house and they need to spend a lot of money on transportation, Mrs. Phon L. asks for a loan to buy a motorbike for her two children.  She hopes this can reduce her family expanses.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her two children to travel to work.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam is 35 years old and married with 4 children. She became a food seller in 1998. Every day she works from 8 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Maryam now hopes for a loan to buy more food items like rice, maize flour and bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Shiv

texts.en: Mr. Shiv T. is a construction worker in Roka Village in Kandal Province. He is a 36-year-old widower with three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while two are attending school. Since Mr. Shiv T.'s family lives in poor conditions and he cannot afford to fix his house, Mr. Shiv T. decided to ask for a loan to repair his house to live more easily.

loans.use: To repair his house in order to live more easily.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 36 years old. She is married. She has been a food seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Asia now hopes for a loan to buy more rice, maize flour, and vegetables for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her inventory

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en: Mrs. Nhem M. is a villager in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie Village in Kandal Province. She is 35 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending school while the other is too young. Her husband, Mr. Thorn Tha, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support his family.  She is a fruit seller in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she asks for a loan to buy different kinds of fruit to meet her customers' demand. Mrs. Nhem M. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of fruit to meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 45 years old and married. She has been a cow keeper since 1995. Every day she works from 6 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Mwajuma now hopes for a loan to improve her business by adding the number of her cows and buying enough food for them.

loans.use: To increase her stock by cows

loans.name: Ol

texts.en: Mrs. Ol S. is 33 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom assists the father in the fishing business while the others are too young to work or attend school. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.  Mrs. Ol S. lives in the village of Ta Skor Village in Kandal Province. She is a fish seller who gets fish from her husband, Mr. Pon Oun, to sell.   Aside from this business, Mr. Pon Oun is a house construction worker. Mr. Pon Oun's first business now faces a problem because his boat is too old to gather fish. In order to start this business again, Mrs. Ol S. asks for a loan to buy a new boat for her husband.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a new boat for her husband to start his business again.

loans.name: Agata

texts.en:
Agata is married and has been selling fruit since 2006. Every day, she works from 8AM to 5PM at her business and earns a monthly profit of around US$ 60 from her sales.

Agata is now requesting a loan in order to purchase more fruit for re-sale. She hopes that with this loan, she will be able to continue to expand her business and reach out to more customers.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit for re-sale

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Mr. Phon N. is 48 years old and the father of four children who are all attending junior high school.  He is a construction worker in Preak Ta Ong Ti Bey Village in Kandal Province. His wife, Mrs. Song Thy, is a mat maker. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it but she does not have enough money to buy more raw materials to make mats. Therefore, her husband, Mr. Phon N., asks for a loan for his wife.  Mr. Phon N. and his wife are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to make mats.

loans.name: Asha's Maendeleo B Group

texts.en:
Asha is 51 years old. She is married with 9 children. She has been a fruit seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more fruit for re-sale. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with tailoring, cafe ownership, and food shop ownership.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more fruit for re-sale.

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mr. Mean Y. was born in 1987 and he now lives in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie village in Kandal Province. He owns a small cart with a horse in order to transport soil to sell door-to-door. His wife, Mrs. Sen Chantrea, is a mat maker in the local village. They live separately, with their parents, because they do not have enough money to build a new house. In order to live independently, Mr. Mean Y. works hard and now asks for a loan to start a horse breeding business.  He hopes to increase his income and improve his living conditions and live separately from his parents soon. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To start a horse breeding business.

loans.name: Hadia's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Hadia is 24 years old. She is single with 3 children between 8 and 3 years old. She became a food seller in 2003. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Hadia now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mwatima R., Mosi B., and Mwatima A..

loans.use: To by more food items for her business.

loans.name: Fatma's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 45 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 15 and 12. She became a bites seller in 1998. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to expand her business by increasing her inventory. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Hawa and Zawadi.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Kheav

texts.en: Mrs. Kheav N. was born in 1963 and lives in Phlov Trei Village in Kandal Province.  Her husband, Mr. Chum Phally, is a fisherman. Mrs. Kheav N. has six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while four attend junior high school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. She is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. During the rainy season, she cultivates rice while she grows vegetable in dry season. It is now the rainy season so she needs to cultivate rice. In order to do the planting, Mrs. Kheav N. asks for a loan to hire the laborer with two oxen to plow the field and to buy fertilizer to support the field, including pesticides to prevent all kinds of insects from damaging her crop.  Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To  hire the laborer with two oxen to plow the field and to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Phann

texts.en: Mrs. Phann C. is a villager in Trea Village in Kandal Province. She is 40 years old and the mother of a young child.  She and her husband, Mr. Sieng Sophal, own a small restaurant where they sell Chinese noodles, ricepots, fried rice and drinks. Aside from this business, they are farmers. On their plantation, Mrs. Phann C. does not have enough money to buy fertilizer and pesticide. Therefore, Mrs. Phann C. asks for a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Zuwena's Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Zuwena is married with 8 children between the ages of 24 and 2. She has been a charcoal and juice seller since 1998. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Zuwena now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Rahma, Salma, Fatma, and Amina.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is 27 years old, married, and has one 2-year-old child. She has been operating her own card design and creation business since 2006. Every month, she can earn a profit of around $185 from her sales.

Asha would like to continue her business and is now requesting a loan in order to expand her customer base and improve the quality of her service.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing her inventory

loans.name: Hab

texts.en:
Mr. P. Hab, 55, is a wooden house builder who lives in Samproch Commune, Kampong Thom Province. He builds Khmer-style houses in his area and others depending on the demand of customers. He lives with his wife and four children, one of whom is employed at a garment factory in Phnom Penh and earns $100 monthly to help support the family as well. Hab is a skilled builder who learned from his parents. He also has a few employees. His wife is a farmer growing rice and vegetables.

Now he faces the obstacle of lacking construction tools, so he decided to request a loan to purchase construction tools for his building business.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools for his building business

loans.name: Time's Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Time is 40 years old. She is married with 5 children between the ages of 10 and 4 years old. She has been a firewood seller since 2003. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Time now hopes for a loan to buy more firewood for resale. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mchanga, Asha, Zuhura, and Zainab.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for resale

loans.name: Husna

texts.en:
Husna is 36 years old. She is married. She takes care of 1 person aged 50. She has been a fish, juice, and ice-cream seller since 2006. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $215 from her sales.

Husna now hopes for a loan to buy more fish and other items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish and other items for her business.

loans.name: Sultane

texts.en: Sultane I. is a 38-year-old woman who keeps a store where she sells different kind of goods. She started her business in 2002 in her home town Saatli. She is married and has 2 daughters. Sultane applied for 1000 AZN to purchase more food and expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase more food and expand  business.

loans.name: Zuhura's Atoae Ni Mungu Group

texts.en:
Zuhura is 30 years. She is married with two children; they are 12 and 8 years old. She has been a fish and soap seller since 2005. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Zuhura now hopes for a loan to buy more fish and soap for resale. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Chiku and Rukia.

loans.use: To buy more fish and soap for her business

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene is 27 years old. She cares for her parent, who is 50 years old. She has been selling bread Chapati since 2003. Every day, she works from the morning to 1 PM at her business. She can earn a monthly profit or around $185 from her sales.

Rene is now requesting a loan to improve her business by purchasing more food items to increase her sale volume and expand her customer base.

loans.use: To restock her business

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en: Teymur A. is 24-year-old man who sell fruits and vegetables in the central bazaar of the Saatli region. He has 4  years of experience in this field. He lives with his parents, and his business is the only income source for his family. Teymur applied for $1200 USD to improve the conditions of his store.

loans.use: To improve conditions of his store

loans.name: Hafsa

texts.en:
Hafsa is 39 years old. She is married with 7 children, aged between 6 and 23 years old. She owns and runs a small shop. Every day, she works from 7am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Hafsa now hopes for a loan to buy more products for her business.

loans.use: To buy more products for her business.

loans.name: Mushviq

texts.en:
Mushviq I. is a 38-year-old man who keeps a food store. He started his business in 1985 and since that time he has continued working in his home region, Saatli. He is married and has 2 sons; they study at school.

As Mushviq and his wife are otherwise unemployed, keeping this food store is the only financial resource for their family. He has applied for a loan in the amount of 1200 USD to purchase more goods and expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for re-sale and expand his business

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia is 25 years old. She is married with 2 children, aged 1 and 3 years old. She has been a perfume and clothes seller since 2005. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Safia now hopes for a loan to buy more perfumes for her business.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Salama's Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Salama is 38 years old. She is married with 6 children, aged 6 to 22 years old. She became a food seller in 2006. Every day, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Salama now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Huzuni, Farashuu, Aibu and Hawa.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Mwashamba's Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Mwashamba is 34 years old and married with 6 children, aged between 2 and 15 years old. She became a food seller in 2005. Every day she works from 8 AM to 4 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Mwashamba now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Hudhaima, Ramla and Amina.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her stock.

loans.name: Khasanaga

texts.en: Khasanaga H. is a 59-year-old trader who has had a food store since 1983. He is married and has four children. He lives with his family in the southern village of Saatli region. He is an engineer, but in the region where he lives, it is impossible to find a job related to his profession, so Khasanaga`s main source of income is his food store. He would like to improve the conditions of the store, and for this purpose, he has applied for a 1200 USD loan.

loans.use: Improving conditions of store

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is 30 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 14, 10 and 4. She has been a charcoal seller since 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 6:50pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Khadija now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for re-sale.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is 25 years old. She is married with 1 child aged 2 years old. She is a fish seller. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for re-sale.

loans.use: To buy more fish for re-sale

loans.name: Subira

texts.en:
Subira is married with 7 children aged between 12 and 27 years old. She has owned and run a small beauty salon since 2005. Every day, she works from 10am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her services.

Subira now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business

loans.name: Bimize

texts.en:
Bimize is 35 years old. She is married with 4 children aged 14, 12, 10 and 3 years old. She owns and runs a small butcher shop, and she has been a shoe seller since 2003. Every day, she works at her businesses and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Bimize now hopes for a loan to buy more shoes and meat for her businesses.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and meat for her businesses

loans.name: Leap's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Leap Y. is a group leader of a small group who lives in Svay Por Commune, Battambang Province. She makes soybean juices and sells them in the car park near the market, which is a profitable locatiO.. She has been selling juice for eighteen years and typically earns around $2.5 per day. Her husband is a barber in his area, earning approximately $5 per day. She lives with her husband and has five children, two of whom are married.

She's growing her soybean juice business due to increasing of demand of customers. She needs to expand her business, but she doesn’t have enough money. She decided to request a loan from Kiva to purchase more soybeans to make juice.

Mrs. Sam At O. is requesting a loan to buy more ingredients for her cooked rice and porridge selling business. Mrs. Savin S. is requesting a loan to purchase materials for her photography business.

loans.use: To purchase more soybeans for making juice

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is married with 4 children aged 20, 18, 16, and 5 years old. She became a tailor in 1988. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Saumu Salmini Group

texts.en:
Saumu is 35 years old. She is married with 6 children aged between 8 and 20 years old. She has been a juice and spices seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Saumu now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with firewood sales, charcoal sales, livestock raising, and clothes and handbag sales.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Madame Kadiatou Diakité est âgée de  27 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants et son mari dans une famille monogame au  quartier Heremakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (préfecture de Bougouni troisième région économique de la république du Mali).
Ayant vite abandonné les études pour des raisons sociales, elle mena plusieurs  activités génératrices de revenus sans succès mais finit par se spécialiser depuis maintenant 8 ans dans l’achat vente des vêtements d’occasion autrement dit la friperie. Elle a appris cette activité  auprès d’une amie.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires Madame Kadiatou Diakité a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est à sa première expérience.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 3 balles de vêtements d’occasion de différentes variétés (pour enfants, draps et serviettes). Elle méne cette activité devant son domicile à Heremakono Nord et au marché de Bougouni tous les (jeudi) jours de foire, où elle réalise le plus de vente. Elle a une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes, de hotels et exerce cette activité durant toute l’année. 
Elle s’approvisionne généralement  à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des sociétés importatrices des friperies et en république du Burkina Faso.
 Madame Kadiatou Diakité  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, aider  son mari à assurer les dépenses de la famille (santé, éducation, nourriture, etc....) et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadiatou Diakité, 27, lives with her two children and her husband in a monogamous family in the Heremakono Nord neighborhood of the town of Bougouni (Bougouni Prefecture, third economic region of the Republic of Mali.)

Having abandoned her studies early for societal reasons, she tried several different money-earning activities without success and ended up specializing for the past 8 years in selling fairly used clothing. She learned this business from a friend.

In her search for complementary financial resources, Mrs. Kadiatou Diakité decided to join the credit program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom she is having her first experience as a borrower.

She intends to use this loan to buy three bales of used clothing of different sorts (for children, sheets and napkins). She runs her business out of her home in Heremakono Nord and at the market in Bougouni on Thursday market days. She has a clientele essentially composed of women and of hotels and works at this business all year round.

She generally buys her merchandise in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from companies that import used clothing and in the Republic of Burkina Faso.

Mrs. Kadiatou Diakité hopes to make a monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to help her husband cover family expenses (health, education, food, etc.). She will reinvest any remainder in her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of used clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Yekaterina

texts.en:
Yekaterina is K. is a hard working market vendor from Nikolaev, Ukraine. She runs a small business selling leather clothing items in the local market place called "Kolos".  Several years ago, she recognized the value of being self-employed. She chose to sell practical and durable items that are always in demand. 

Yekaterina has requested a loan of 2500 Grivnas to open another market stall and increase her available working capital. We have been happy to provide Yekaterina with financial assistance in the past and look for to continuing to help her business grow and thrive in the future.

Note: This is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To open another market stall

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is married with one daughter. After college she had several different jobs, however, she realized that her best opportunity would be to have her own business. Today Svetlana is in business selling trendy clothing and footwear at the local market. She has been in this trade for 10 years.

Svetlana is very sociable. Her friendliness and respectful attitude have given her a good reputation at the market. Svetlana has also proven to be a good manager of her finances. She has promptly repaid all her loans from Nadiya Ukraine. Loans have enabled a gradual expansion of Svetlana's business. Currently, she has about $15,000 in inventory. Her gross income per month is about $2000. Her monthly net profit amounts to $500.

Svetlana would like to get a loan for 3000 Grivnas to increase the assortment of inventory in her kiosk. She believes the loan will be beneficial to her business by promoting its expansion. Profit generated by her business will help Svetlana cover some necessities at home to improve the quality of life for her family.

Note: this is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam Konaté a 34 ans et vit dans une famille monogame avec son enfant et son mari au quartier Koko de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative du Mali)
Dès son jeune âge elle s’interessa aux activités génératrices de revenus telle la coiffure qu’elle fut obligée d’abandonner pour des raisons de santé. Finalement elle se spécialise dans le commerce de tissus: pagnes wax, des bazins( blancs  ou teints),  tissus brodés et divers articles pour femmes depuis maintenant 7 ans.  
Madame Mariam Konaté est à son premier prêt avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 10 pièces de tissus brodés au marché de Koutiala ( troisième région économique du Mali) et  à Bobo Dioulaso ( en République du Burkina Faso en Afrique de l’Ouest) auprès des grossistes de la lingerie vestimentaire.
Elle vend ses marchandises chez elle à domicile et de façon ambulante au niveau des entreprises de Koutiala  à une clientèle de femmes et d’hommes à crédit (payable mensuellement) ou au comptant.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 75.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage d’utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. Madame Mariam Konaté  compte ouvrir une boutique pour la vente de tissus brodés et divers.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariam Konaté is 34 years old and lives in a monogamous family with her child and her husband in the Koko neighborhood in the Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of Mali). From a young age, she was interested in businesses, such as hairdressing, which she was forced to quit for health reasons. In the end, she has specialized in selling fabrics: wax pagnes (traditional wrap around), damask (white or dyed), embroidered fabrics and various items for women, which she has been doing for 7 years. Mrs. Mariam Konaté is on her first loan with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program. She plans to use this loan to buy 10 pieces of embroidered fabric at the market in Koutiala (third economic region of Mali) and in Bobo Dioulaso (in the Republic of Burkina Faso in West Africa) from fashion linen wholesalers. She sells her merchandise at home and traveling around to companies in Koutiala to a clientele of women and men on credit (payable monthly) or for cash. She expects to turn a profit of 75,000 CFA francs per month, which she plans to use to make loan payments and contribute to the daily expenses of her family. Mrs. Mariam Konaté plans to open a boutique selling embroidered and various other fabrics.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase embroidered fabrics

loans.name: Nina

texts.en:
Nina operates a small business offering hairdressing services in Primorsk, Ukraine. She has an attractively arranged little facility in her home town where she does all sorts of haircuts and hairstyles for her female customers. Nina's business has developed into a stable, profitable enterprise, based on services that are always in demand. Her business has become the main source of income for her and her family. In a typical month she gets around $1000 in gross revenue.

Nina's business is growing and her clientele is consistently increasing. She has requested a loan of 1000 Grivnas to increase her working capital and help boost the further development of her business.

Note: this is a short term "express" loan that will be repaid in a month.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is an entrepreneur from Primorsk, where she runs a small business selling linen sheets, terrycloth towels and robes. Ludmila regularly re-stocks her inventory and offers customer-friendly service which makes her vending facility an attractive spot for many potential customers. Currently, Ludmila has about $7000 in turnover capital.

Ludmila is very thorough with all her suppliers and merchandise. She is in charge of all quality checks to make sure all inventory is flawless and durable, too. Ludmila is seeking a loan for 2500 Grivnas to increase her inventory and eventually open one more vending facility in her home town.

Note: this is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Mohammad Haleem

texts.en:
Mohammad Haleem is 50 years old. He is married and has 5 children. He has a construction supplies shop that he has been involved in for more than 20 years. He has already 28000 Afghani invested in his shop and also one of his sons is working with Haleem. His shop is located in a good area in Kabul and he has a good number of customers, but he wants to import more supplies from Pakistan.

Therefore, he has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani with a term of 18 months to import more supplies and bolster his business. He would like to enlarge his shop and make a good monthly income to support his family.

Haleem is very happy with this loan. He hopes to work hard and marry off his son. It is one of his best wishes in his life to see his son married. He would like to thank AFSG and Kiva who make this opportunity to help human for human possible.

loans.use: To import more supplies

loans.name: Danaya (Trust) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Danaya  (trois mariées et une célibataire )ont une moyenne d’âge de  28 ans et  2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames traditionnelles au quartier Sogomougou de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région économique du Mali ).
Elles mènent différentes activités notamment  la vente de bois pour la construction, la restauration ( exclusivement nocturne) etc. Unis par des liens professionnel, de voisinage et de groupe d’âge, les membres du groupe dans leur souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans.
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire) et les deux premiers ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter la contenance d‘un camion en bois de constuction, un sac de haricot, des cartons de macaronie et une quantité importante d’ingrédients pour la restauration. Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages voisins de Koutiala auprès des exploitants forestiers pour le bois de construction et au grand marché de la ville pour les ingrédients de la restauration nocturne.
Les entrepreneurs du batiment sont les principaux clients du bois de construction. Par contre la clientèle est très diversifiée pour la restauration en raison de la proximité du lieu de vente à une zone très fréquentée par les noctambules. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice par cycle de 80 000 CFA.qu’elles envisagent utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The four women in the Danaya group (three are married and one is single) are on average 28 years old and have two children. They live in traditional polygamist families in the Sogomougou neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (third economic region of Mali). They run different businesses, notably in the sale of construction wood, food-service (exclusively at night), etc. United by profession, neighborhood, and age, in trying to grow their businesses, the group members decided to use microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program, which they have been doing for two years. They are on their third group loan, and their first two were repaid without difficulty. The current loan will be used to buy a truckload of construction wood, a bag of beans, boxes of macaroni, and a large quantity of ingredients for their food-service business. They stock up in Koutiala’s neighboring villages from forest farmers for the construction wood and at the city’s big market for the ingredients for the nocturnal food-service. Building entrepreneurs are the principal clients of the construction wood. On the other hand, the food-service clientele is diversified because of the proximity of the location to an area frequented by night owls. They hope to earn 80,000 CFA francs each per cycle, which they foresee using to make loan payments and meet the ongoing needs of their families.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction wood and ingredients for food-service

loans.name: Assitan

texts.fr:
Madame Assitan C. est âgée de 33 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants, elle vit dans une famille monogame au quartier Pelengana Nord de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région économique du Mali).
Après avoir tenté plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus pendant  des années auprès de sa mère adoptive, elle décida il y a maintenant  5 ans de se spécialiser dans l’achat vente des chaussures en cuirs, des sacs pour femmes et maintenant la vente de miche de pain.
Pour obtenir des ressources financières additionnelles, elle décida de faire recours au programme crédit de l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso (depuis maintenant 3 ans) afin de mieux satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante. Après avoir bouclé trois prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son  deuxième prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 1 000 miches de pains, 40 sacs à main et 40 paires de chaussures
Elle s’approvisionne en sacs à mains et en chaussures à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des artisans spécialisés dans la maroquinerie. Par contre elle s’approvisionne en pain auprès d’une boulangerie avec laquelle elle a signé une convention d’exclusivité. Les sacs et les chaussures sont vendus à domicile et au grand marché de la ville de Ségou (au comptant, à crédit, en ambulant ou de façon fixe) surtout les lundi jour de foire (où elles réalisent le plus de vente). 
Disposant d’installation spécialisée pour la vente du pain, elle vend sa marchandise à des hommes et des femmes (principalement des villageois) qui viennent s’approvisionner pour aller revendre dans leurs villages respectifs. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, contribuer aux charges de la famille et investir le reste dans les affaires. Son rêve est de devenir une commerçante import export dans le futur.
texts.en:
Mrs. Assitan C. is 33 years old and a married mother of 4. She lives in a monogamous family in the Pelengana Nord neighborhood in the city of Ségou (fourth economic region of Mali). After having attempted several business for years with her adoptive mother, she decided 5 years ago to specialize in buying and selling leather shoes, women’s handbags, and loaves of bread. In order to secure additional resources, she decided to turn to microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program (3 years ago) to be able to better satisfy the needs of her growing clientele. After having secured three group loans with an association in her neighborhood, she is now on her second individual loan. All of the preceding loans were properly repaid. She plans to use this loan to buy 1,000 loaves of bread, 40 handbags, and 40 pairs of shoes. She gets her handbags and shoes from Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from artisans specializing in leather goods. She gets her bread from a bakery with which she has signed an exclusivity agreement. The bags and shoes are sold at home and at the big market in the city of Ségou (for cash or credit, traveling or on the spot) usually on Mondays, the market days (when sellers sell the most). Taking care of the special setup to sell bread, she sells her goods to men and women (principally villagers) who come to stock up in order to resell in their respective villages. She hopes to earn 30,000 CFA francs monthly, which will be used towards making loan payments and contributing to her family’s expenses – the rest will be invested in her business. Her dream is to become an importer-exporter in the future.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy and sell bread, shoes, and handbags

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame   Fatoumata   Traoré est âgée de 28 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 3 enfants dans une famille monogame à Sido Soninkoura un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région économique du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce du bois de chauffe depuis maintenant 3 ans. 
Elle est en relation avec l’institution Soro Yiriwaso il y’a de cela 3 ans. Après avoir bouclé 3 prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son premier prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou et quelques fois dans les villages environnants (tel Kélékou) en bois de chauffe auprès des paysans officiellement reconnus dans la profession. Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 5 chargements de bois de camion de bois de chauffe.
Elle vend à la maison nuit et jour (car dispose d’un endroit aménagé où les bois sont stockés à l’abri de la pluie.). Madame Fatoumata Traoré vend en détail, en gros à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes et de boulangers qui sont ravitaillés à crédit remboursable hebdomadairement..
Son avantage dans cette activité est qu’elle n’a pas de concurrent car elle est la seule vendeuse de bois de chauffe de son quartier. Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 115.000 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités. Son ambition est de diversifier ses activités en ouvrant une boutique d’articles divers.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré is 28 years old and lives with her husband and 3 children in a monogamous family in Sido Soninkoura, one of the outlying neighborhoods in the town of Segou (the fourth economic area of Mali).

She never attended school due to social reasons. Very quickly she started a business to generate an income, more specifically,for the last three years, she has been selling firewood. For the last 3 years, she has had a relationship with the organization Soro Yiriwaso. After having completed 3 group loans (interdependent loans) with a neighborhood association, she is applying for her first individual loan. All the previous loans have been repaid on time.

She gets her firewood supply on Segou's plaza and sometimes in the surrounding villages (such as Kélékou). She buys from farmers well known in the trade. She plans on using this loan to buy 5 truck loads of firewood.

She sells from her home day and night (because she uses a space set aside where the wood is stored, sheltered form the rain). Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré sells retail and wholesale mostly to women and bakers who buy on credit that is repayable weekly. Her advantage in this business is that she has no competition because she is the only seller of firewood in her neighborhood. She is planning on making a monthly profit of 115.000 FCFA which will allow her to both repay the loan and invest the rest in her activity. Her ambition is to diversify her activity by opening a shop selling various items.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nyètaa (Le Progrès). Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres (cinq mariés et une veuve) du groupe Nyètaa de l’association Benkadi ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Hamdallaye A de la ville de Ségou (Région de Ségou République du Mali)
Liées par des relations professionnelles, de voisinage et d’amitié ces femmes du groupe Nyetaa exercent essentiellement l’activité d’achat, de teinture et vente de bazins. Elles ont été initiée à cette activité génératrice de revenus  grâce à une  formation du département de la promotion de la femme de Ségou. Avec 5 ans d’expériences dans le metier, elles jouissent d’une grande réputation dans la localité de Ségou et reçoivent ainsi beaucoup de commandes surtout lors des cérémonies (mariage, Bapteme etc...) et des fêtes (Tabaski, Ramadan etc...).
Dans leurs recherches de ressources financières complémentaires pour satisfaire leur clientèle de plus en plus grandissante elles sollicitent la collaboration de Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont en relation depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après 6 prêts de groupe tous  correctement remboursés, le groupe va utiliser le septième pour acheter 31 pièces de bazin et une importante quantité de teintures de  potasse et le payement de la facture d’eau. .Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako et à Ségou en matières premières (bazins blancs, potasse et teintures) Elles teintent leurs tissus dans leur atelier. Ensuite elle les revendent au comptant ou à crédit; généralement aux revendeuses des bazins teintés de Bamako, Kolongo, Macina, Dioro, Niono, quelques fois même à l’extérieur (Cotonou et Lagos)., aux couturiers et à certaines femmes de leurs quartier.  
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice par cycle de 125.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour subvenir aux dépenses de la famille, payer les intérêts du prêt et renforcer son activité de teinture. De façon générale, elles ont comme objectif la création d’un centre de teinture pour les femmes.
texts.en:
The six members (five married and a widow) of the group Nyètaa of the association Benkadi are, on average, 32 years old and have, on average 3 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye A in the town of Ségou (Ségou Region, Republic of Mali).

United by professional, neighborly and friendship ties, the activity of these women, from the group Nyetaa, consists mainly of buying, dying and selling bazins (cloth). They were introduced to this income producing activity thanks to a training from the Department for the Enhancement of Women in Ségou. They have 5 years of experience in this trade, and enjoy a large reputation in the town of Ségou. They receive a lot of orders, essentially for big celebrations (weddings, baptisms etc...) and for parties (Tabaski, Ramadan etc...).

In order to meet their ever-increasing clients' demands, they are looking for additional financial resources. They are requesting the collaboration of Soro Yiriwaso with whom they have had a relationship for the last 3 years. After 6 group loans, all paid back on time, the group will use the seventh one to buy 31 pieces of bazins (cloth), a considerable quantity of dyes and potash, and to pay the water bill. They do their buying of raw material (white bazins, potash and dyes) in Bamako and in Ségou. They dye their fabric in their workshop. Then, they sell them for cash or on credit, usually to resellers of dyed bazins in Bamako, Kolongo, Macina, Dioro, Niono and sometimes even over the border (Cotonou and Lagos), to seamstresses and to some women in their neighborhood.

They hope to each make a profit of 125.000 FCFA per cycle. They will use it mainly to cover their families expenses, to pay off the loan and to bolster their dyeing activity. In general, their goal is to create a dyeing center for women.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bazins, dyes, and potash

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Madame Djeneba C. a 39 ans et vit avec son époux et son enfant à Darsalam un des quartiers du village de Farako préfecture de Sikasso( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Dès son jeune age elle s’est intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente de céréales et d’atièkè (semoule alimentaire fait à base de manioc ou d’igname sauvage que les restaurateurs assaisonnent et vendent avec du poisson) depuis maintenant 10 ans.
Après 3 ans de partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso elle a obtenu 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter 15 sacs de haricot et 40 sacs d’ atièkè. Madame Djeneba C. s’approvisionne en haricot dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants de la ville de Ségou  auprès des paysans producteurs de cette spéculation. Quant à l’atièké il est acheté auprès des grossistes ivoiriens fournissant les commerçants du grand marché de la ville de Sikasso. Avec une clientèle essentiellement composée de restaurateurs de ménagères et de revendeurs, Madame Djeneba C. vend quelque fois à crédit payable mensuellement, au comptant, à domicile et au marché les jours de foire.
Madame Djeneba C.  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille et  investir le reste dans les activités. Dans l’avenir elle veut devenir grossiste d’atièkè pour ravitailler les commerçants détaillants de la commune rurale de Finkolo, Farako et les villages environnants.
texts.en:
Madame Djeneba C. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and son in Darsalam, a neighborhood of Farako village in Sikasso prefecture (the third largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). From a young age she has been interested in income-generating activities, particularly selling grains and "atièkè" (cassava- or wild yam-based semolina that restaurant owners season and sell with fish) which she has been doing for over ten years now. Following three years of partnership with Soro Yiriwaso, she received three solidarity loans (group loans) and is on her second individual loan. All of these previous loans have been properly repaid. With this loan, she intends to buy 15 bags of beans and 40 bags of atièkè. Madame Djeneba C. gets her supply of beans from small farmers involved in this trade at weekly markets in the villages near Ségou. The atièkè she gets from Ivoirian wholesalers who stock traders in the main city market of Sikasso. Her customer base is made up mostly of home restaurant owners and resalers; Madame Djeneba C. sometimes sells on weekly credit, for cash, at homes and in the market on market days. Madame Djeneba C. envisions making a weekly profit of 40,000 Francs CFA that will be used to pay the interest on her loan, to contribute to her family's expenses, and the rest to invest in her business. In the future she would like to become a wholesaler of atièkè supplying retailers in the rural commune of Finkolo, Farako, and the surrounding villages.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beans and atiéké.

loans.name: Mwaka's Salmini Group

texts.en:
Mwaka is 45 years old and married. She takes care of 3 children aged 3 years old. She is a livestock keeper and she has been a firewood seller since 1990. Every day she works from 7 AM to 8 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Mwaka now hopes for a loan to increase her inventory. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with the sale of clothes, perfumes, soft drinks and firewood.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Fatimata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatimata G. est âgée de  41 ans et vit dans une famille traditionnelle élargie avec ses 3 enfants (1 garçon et 2 filles), son époux, sa belle mère et les autres parents de son époux à Kaboïla I, un quartier central de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle décida d’entreprendre l’achat  vente d’habillements depuis maintenant 6 ans.
Elle est en relation avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans. Après avoir bénéficié de 5 prêts de groupe ( prêt solidaire) avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son 5 ème prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.  
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter 500 paires de chaussures de qualités différentes (Talons, Chaussures en plastique et d’enfants) à Bamako et 10 pièces de Brodé de qualités différentes à Lomé (République du togo), Conakry (République de guinée conakry) et Accra (République du Ghana).
Elle revend ses marchandises en détail (au comptant ou à crédit) dans sa boutique située au grand marché de Sikasso à une clientèle constituée en majorité de femmes et surtout de foraines.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFAqui servira à résoudre l’essentiel de ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille,  payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité. Elle souhaite dans l’avenir devenir une commerçante grossiste s’occupant de l’import export afin de fournir les détaillants de Sikasso.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatimata G. is 41 years old and has a traditional family which has grown to include three (3) children (1 boy and 2 girls), her husband, mother-in-law and other relatives of her husband. She lives in Kaboila, a neighborhood in the center of the city of Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After several unsuccessful attempts at other businesses, she decided, six years ago, to go into the business of buying and selling clothing. She has had an association with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinancing bank for five years. She has profited from five (5) group loans made with a neighborhood association and is also on her fifth personal loan, all of which have been successfully repaid.

With this loan she plans to buy 500 pairs of various quality shoes (heeled, plastic and children shoes) at Bamako and 10 pieces of Brodé (embroidered fabric) of different quality at Lomé (Republic of Togo), Conakry (Republic of Guinea-Conakry) and Accra (Republic of Ghena). She will sell this merchandise as single items (for cash or credit) in her boutique located in the central marketplace at Sikasso. Her clientele is made up mostly of women and many local stall owners.

She expects to produce a monthly profit of 200,000 francs CFA which will be used primarily, to pay personal expenses, contribute to family expenses, meet the payments of the loan and invest the remainder in her business activity. She would like to become an import-export wholesaler to supply retailers in Sikasso.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of embroidered fabric and shoes

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia is a widow with 3 children aged 14, 10, and 8 years old. She has been a juice, eggs and oil seller since 2003. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Safia now hopes for a loan to buy more more items to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Mwanahamisi's Haki Na Lawama Group

texts.en:
Mwanahamisi is 28 year old and married with 3 children, aged 10, 3 and 1. She has been a fish and spice seller since 1999. Every day she works from 7 AM to 9 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Mwanahamisi now hopes for a loan to buy more fish and spices for sale. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses dealing with charcoal sales, fish sales, clothes sales and a retail shop.

loans.use: To buy more fish and spices for sale.

loans.name: Zakia's Hakia Na Lawama Group

texts.en:
Zakia S. is 45 years old and is married with a 10-year-old child. She started a business selling snacks in 2000. Every day she works from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35  from her sales.

Zakia now hopes for a loan to improve her business by increasing her stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have  businesses dealing with clothes sales, oil sales and tailoring.

loans.use: To improve her business.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is 40 years old. She is married with 5 children between 21 and 4. She also takes care of 1 other person, aged 80. She has been a fruit, firewood, and spices seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Riziki now hopes for a loan to buy more firewood, fruit, and spices to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Kesi's Jambo Nia Group

texts.en:
Kesi is 42 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 5 and 3. She has been a charcoal and soap seller since 1999. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Kesi now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and soap for re-sale. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Zainab, who owns a shop.

loans.use: To  buy more charcoal and soap for re-sale

loans.name: Nilda Y Enma Group

texts.es:
Nilda and Enma are members of the Community Bank Rikchary which means "Wake up" in Quechua.

Nilda is married, 37 years old, and has 3 children. She sells cosmetics through catalogs which she offers to her friends. She also has a car which she rents out. This generates daily income for her.
